{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3436447,"name":"Christine Low","username":"SurfGear","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/surfgear/{size}/120560_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-18T15:14:26.362Z","cooked":"

Event: Battle at the Border (Oct 12-13 2024) San Diego
Test Bumps:
Red bumps

  • 3/4" 7-layer Baltic birch plywood
  • TPU corner “padding” (see pics below)
  • finger-jointed corners with Titebond3 wood glue
  • 1# (# = pound per cubic foot) solid-core 2.6" dia solid “Oodles of Noodles” padding (PE foam)

Blue bumps:

  • 3/4" 7-layer Baltic birch plywood
  • TPU corner “padding”
  • finger-jointed corners with Titebond3 wood glue
  • 1.3# backer rod 2.5" dia (from “Oodles”) padding

Note 1: 3D printed TPU corners are not legal, probably never will be. This is a prototype for a corner padding piece with better characteristics than pool noodle foam. Something that protects the bumper backing and robot, allows an elastic collision (aka “bumper car bumpers”), variable-spring-characteristics, durable for at least 1 season if not more.
Since I can’t injection mold, 3D printed TPU is the best I’ve got right now.

image1920×1315 98.3 KB

image1419×1753 132 KB

image1344×1569 110 KB

image1319×1399 135 KB

image1446×1671 165 KB

image547×875 53.1 KB

Manufacturing notes:

  • Fabric covering left the tops of the TPU corners exposed so we could see any damage if it occurred (no damage seen) and so that other teams could tell these bumps were different
  • Bumpers were NOT “fully backed up” to the robot frame perimeter. This is an ongoing battle, arguments abound. Them: “It’s hard to get the bumps on!” Me: “That’s the whole point! Like sausage and Spanx, it’s supposed to be tight!”. Believe we had 1/4" gap between robot and bumps in multiple places.
  • Fabric was stapled using my “clamp the bumps to a table and compress, so the fabric is TIGHT” method, which was a mistake. This method was great with hollow noodles, which compress permanently with a few hits.
  • Solid noodles & backer rod did NOT compress, so the seams eventually failed.
  • Failed seams/no fabric covering is BAD, as we learned when practicing at Code Orange.
    image1204×1208 204 KB

Recommendation: Do NOT compress solid bumper padding when you staple on the fabric covering.

BatB Competition: These bumps were run on our 2024 competition robot. Hits were very hard, primary driver didn’t slow down. Incurred significant damage to our (over the bumper) intake as it was deployed when it hit… everything?

Results:
Fabric seams at the corners began to fail at the end of day 1. Covered with duct tape.
In the last match of the 2nd day, duct tape was ripped off, seam failed completely, and one TPU Corner was ripped clean off the robot (only 4 screws held the corner to the plywood). Can’t find a pic of that.

image1186×1022 147 KB

Post-competition, the fabric was removed from both bumps for inspection.
Red & Blue bumps:

  • TPU corners: no internal damage, even the ripped off corner
  • Corners of plywood: fully intact, no glue fracturing

Red bumps:

  • zero damage.
  • 1# pool noodles seem slightly compressed/worn

Blue bumps:

  • 1 fracture (completely through 3/4" ply) and an exterior surface impact “print” that is suspiciously like similar damage from the 2024 competition season.
  • Believe this side of the bump was under our intake (see comment about intake damage).
  • Backer rod at the impact side had a 1/4" deep “slice” running vertically towards the exterior, noodle was expected diameter and texture. But the fabric covering that spot had no damage/slice/tear.
  • Backer rod seemed completely undamaged/unworn otherwise - in better shape than the 1# noodles in red bumps.
    image1331×1714 112 KB

    image1157×1803 120 KB

Intake that was damaged/destroyed:

image1920×873 193 KB

What we learned:

  • Solid padding is better (than hollow pool noodles)
  • Denser padding seems better
  • Back up your bumper to your frame perimeter as much as possible (duh)
  • Protecting the corners is a challenge
  • Don’t make your fabric covering too tight. If you have seams, make them heavy-duty.

What we are trying next:

  • Bumps with vertical padding cylinder (aka “pool noodle”) in the corner WITH a 3D printed TPU support. Historical evidence says that a plywood corner may shear your vertical noodle into pieces.
  • side padding is the same 1.31# backer rod as shown above (it is gray color)
  • corner padding is Foam Factory PE noodles, 2.5" dia and supposed to be 2#, but we measure it at 1.3# (white color)
  • Per the new rules, these should be completely legal. Yes, even the TPU corner supports (as the “hard parts” rule went from 1" to 1.5")
    image876×988 53.1 KB

    image967×1260 104 KB

    image1646×1304 175 KB

4-piece bumps with 2# “slab” cross-linked polyethylene

  • we measured the density at 1.91 #/ft^3
  • used multiple layers of 1" thick foam, glued together with surprisingly thin layers of rubber cement (by far the best adhesive for this stuff)
  • Per the new rules, these should be completely legal.

Very nice corner supporter idea!

Here’s another concept that will pass the “1.5” hard parts" test: a section of 4" sewer pipe (get the solid PVC type, not the cellular type) with a wedge taken out of it. Duct tape in place.
The idea is that the PVC pipe defines a 2.25" radius corner so you don’t have that knife edge slashing through the padding AND adds a bit of spring loaded flex in the system. Yeah, the noodles will look kinda funny. Layered foam sheets wrapped around would be much better here.

image755×814 22.2 KB

Even better is to flat the corner of the 3/4" plywood to add a bit more spring travel: that’s 0.6" of squish room.
You might get fancy and secure ONE side of the pipe in place so it doesn’t migrate off the corner. A groove, block, screws, something…
image706×723 21.3 KB

So, is the idea here that the PVC pipe absorbs some of the energy by flexing during a hard impact and spreads that load into the two sides a bit away from the corner? That’s an interesting concept. I think you would need to secure one end of the PVC pipe to the plywood, but otherwise it seems like it would be an excellent way to absorb energy.

As far as the noodles on the sides that are laying on top of the PVC pipe and are now sitting a bit further away from the bumper, would you try to compress that with the fabric? Having those corners stick out a bit could be a a problem if you have something like the 2023 endgame where you wanted to keep the space that you take up on the switch to a minimum (also applies to the 2020 and 2022 end games where you were sharing limited end game space with other robots). Obviously the best solution would be to scarf the ends of the noodles, but I don’t think that would be legal.

Yes, exactly! The PVC pipe section acts as a spring. Plus it increases the radius of the corner that’s acting on the other bot. The sharp corners cut through the foam and don’t engage very much of it. A larger radius means that you compress much more foam than the sharp corner.

I agree, you would need to anchor one end to keep it from shifting off the corner.

Yeah, all these “exploit the additional hard parts” solutions will increase the projected area of the robots and occupy space…

Running actual calculations

This assumes the span of the supports is the pipe diameter, which is at least in the right ballpark and that the radius is large (not so good).

Using 4" schedule 40 PVC.
Set up for 0.6" deflection; 500 pounds force. 15ksi.
Oops, this is above the yield stress for PVC.
0.3" deflection is right at yield; 252 pounds and 7,500 psi.

Thinning the wall from 0.237" to 0.12" gets you 65 pounds at 7,700 psi.

When I run this for aluminum and steel things get weird and “that doesn’t look right”. I need to make a couple parts and test

image797×752 80.3 KB

Ok, it looks like 4" pvc isnt a bad choice. Theres a LOT of friction as the C is opened. The full 40# my tool will measure is maybe 3/16" of travel on stock 4" schedule 40. Boring it to 1/8" wall (which I DON’T reccomend you do) radically lowers the load: 13# for about 5/8" travel.

Worth remembering that 40lb is a tiny fraction of the forces involved in a robot collision. The testing I’ve seen has collisions in the vicinity of 100Gs, so forces can reach into 10,000lb range.

I agree! They key bit on the corner pipe concept is to engage more foam in the collision, rather than allowing the corner to hack its way through to a wood-wood collision.
I’m still noodling on how to set up for impact testing and trying to get my shock logger set up right.

Since Baltic Birch has been in discussion again, I looked up the standard. Baltic Birch is governed by the Russian GOST 3916.1-96 standard. (Grade B is also referred to as I, BB>II, CP>III) According to the standard, 18mm plywood must be 13 ply, the core veneers’ species must match the face veneer unless marked otherwise, and defects in the core must not affect structural properties. If you have less than 13 ply, its not Baltic Birch. If the core is not birch, its not Baltic Birch. If the core has voids or overlaps, its not Baltic Birch, (or something slipped past QC which happens albeit rarely).

Not everyone needs to use Baltic Birch, but if you are going to, make sure you are actually buying Baltic Birch not cabinet grade birch or some other birch plywood.

I am going to say the quiet part out loud:

Better bumpers are a poor fix for the bigger problem of higher moment impacts. FIRST is turning the bumpers into crumple zones and this is going to get expensive and risky for the mechanisms needed to play the game well. We have already exceeded impact forces required to demolish 1/8" rectangular stock. What’s next? Needing 1/4" stock to manage the impacts?

Additionally, previously, all bumpers were basically the same, so impact forces were evenly distributed between robots - no single bot took more of the force. With the new design expansion, it is going to be very easy to make a battlebot instead of a game-playing bot. The materials available now have wildly different energy absorption characteristics. I am not looking forward to robot demolition derby.

I truly wonder if anyone from a crash testing lab was consulted on any of this, because that should have been the first ask.

/rant

Just throwing an alternative take on the bumper wood / backing conversation. Our bumpers for the 321 robot never broke, and we used home depot plywood. Each side was independent - we used 4 piece, not wrap around, bumpers, with a red set and a blue set. Our bumpers have lasted through 2 district events, DCMP, WCMP (including a day of hard defense on Einstein), IRI, 2 more offseasons, and we’re heading into another in two weeks. The wood shows no signs of splitting, despite not being fully supported by the frame perimeter.

I believe that by not having corner joints in the wood, a major stress concentrator is eliminated. Additionally, our bumpers mounting points aren’t perfectly rigid, so they absorb some of the force of impact.

Our frame is still more or less perfectly square, and bumper wood is fine. Our pool noodles and fabric have certainly degraded, but that is part of life. We’ve played 74 matches on TBA, plus 10ish matches at each of the other two offseasons we attended, plus drive practice, for reference.

I hear you, but there are 2 fixes to momentum speed and mass. Speed is hard to design a rule around and I remember the old brushed motor tank era in FRC it was way less exciting so it goes against the I and R in FIRST. Cutting mass is a great choice for teams to make but I don’t see any good from reducing the weight limit significantly, the well resourced teams who make everything custom can drop weight much more easily than teams using COTS everything.

You bring up differences in bumper cushioning, the working group had access to some test data of all the foam materials allowed for 2025 season, the was only one outlier, and it was hollow noodles, so the discrepancies aren’t getting significantly bigger. The big differences are robot weights not bumpers.

I wasn’t aware of any crash test engineers on the bumper working group, but they design things to crumple and protect a tiny fraction of a car so why are they any better than people who’ve been thinking about FRC bumpers for literal decades?

Here are our lessons learned from this year – 66 matches and innumerable practice hours – enough that although the bumpers are still structurally sound, the numbers are looking a bit sad:

IMG_10571920×1440 284 KB

We gave up on hollow pool noodles a couple of years back – they’re just no longer up to the task. We now use pretty dense solid ones – which might also be “backer rod”, but which we found sold as pool noodles.

We gave up on (the now illegal) wrapped pool noodles after the 2023 season after finding every last one of them shredded at the bend.

Our first attempt at vertical noodle corners wasn’t much more successful:

IMG_09641512×2016 454 KB

It’s practically heresy here on CD, but we have found kiln dried pine to be at least as effective as plywood backer, but we were not satisfied with the performance of ordinary (Titebond III) wood glue on our box corners – the glue failed before the wood. So we used high strength epoxy for our final design for this past (2024) season:

IMG_09871920×1440 224 KB

We are also very careful during glue-up – using a squaring jig and 4 clamps for each corner (clamping in all 3 axes).

One advantage of pine is it left us with enough in our weight budget to reinforce the corners with structural brackets with rounded corners which we believe kept our corner noodles from getting “knifed” by a sharp corner (radiusing your wood corner might be sufficient here). The eagled-eyed might notice we are going with a 3/8" width box joint which gives us almost twice the gluing surface.

We also compress our noodles when putting on the fabric, but it never occurred to us to clamp then to the table to do so, I just press down a bit while the students staple. I suspect this means we compress somewhat less than you do – we’re just interested in the fabric being wrinkle-free. Also we have no seams in our fabric. Each of our U-shaped half bumpers is done with a single piece of fabric with folding and tucking in the corners (and admittedly some students do a better looking job of this than others).

IMG_08031920×1440 184 KB

This year we used more duct tape than ever holding the noodles to the wood, most especially on the front edge, as we were a bit worried about sag over time above our under the bumper intake.

I very much like your 3-d printed corner noodle holder idea.

Working on my side of the bumper testing
Do we want to call it the “sparring partner” or the “punching bag”?

Hyper-robust wood frame, stack it up with 20 pound cinder blocks. Three lag bolted Colsons to simulate a real robot’s ability to slide on the carpet. The shock logger is in the back.
The hammer has a flat face and a corner face so I can test both types of impacts.
All of it is set up to have a 5" tall wood face to hold bumper materials.
This is a two tests with 40# of block in it and flat-flat with bare wood.
The third test is less elevation and point to flat. The last test is with a section of 4" pipe over the corner. I need to space these tests out further

The logger captures the peak acceleration in each 10 second window. Decent enough for a match, slightly annoying that I can’t get more granular for testing… On the cool side, its cheap, battery powered, and it DOES directly compose both PDF files and CSV files from the data when you plug it into your computer!

I may have to dig out some 30 year old B&K accelerometer hardware and try to get some spiffy data!

OK, time for some test data!

Here’s the subjects:

The fake robot gets loaded up with five, 20# cinderblocks. About 50kg including my guess at 10# of wood. Ratchet strapped in.
Fully loaded the dynamic friction from those bolted Colsons is 290 Newtons.

The hammer got 30 pounds of cast iron added to it as low as I could reasonably get it. The hammer itself is well under 5 pounds, so I’m not going to weigh it The CG starts at 10.5" off the ground. I’m using a 48" CG lift height, so the net height for the drop is 37.5" or 0.952 meters. Lets call it 1 meter. So, the input energy is 13.6 kg over 1 meter at 9.8 m/s^2 or 133 Joules. Note that the contact point between the hammer and the target is at the free-hanging point of the hammer; they are just touching.

Sorry, I forgot to take that picture, and its dinner time now!

For reference, a 15 ft/second robot at 120# runs out to 550 Joules
I’ve got hollow petals on the hammer.

The target got our favorite backer rods

My logger records the first hit (with the sparring partner at 50#) at 25.9 gs. The target moved back 33" or 0.83 meters.

The next hit was fully loaded and it rebounded 14" or 0.35m. 23.9 gs was the peak acceleration on the target. That means ROUGHLY 103 Joules went into accelerating the target and 30 Joules was absorbed.

So, the first takeaway is that the wheels limit the energy that can be coupled into a robot. Studded tires will allow you to push this higher than a Colson, of course!

I’ll see about doing a set of impacts to see if the petal noodles get eaten up quickly or not. And how the peak acceleration changes over time. And I need to improve the cinder block anchoring; the top two moved maybe 1/2" toward the hammer.
